list.title: Question 1
list.content:
On the Argand diagram below, the point A represents the complex number
$4i$ and the point B represents the
complex number $−5+i$. The shape
ABCD is a square.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/084ff3dc-81ad-48a1-a00e-266c36989533/images/21388bf0-d67e-42c8-8e7f-57aa7d77f40d/fed41c2307d3c10825aed04db2b46a9169006d2c.svg)


Determine the complex number represented by:


the point C; [2]



the point D. [2]
list.markScheme:
Using the coordinates of the points A and B, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/084ff3dc-81ad-48a1-a00e-266c36989533/images/bf6a50a8-0cb2-4df3-a2ae-1c5acd9cc0b7/0bb5140f7bfb03dc770a8940b3da94e0b2a73825.svg)


From the Argand diagram above, we have:


the point C represents
$−2−4i​$


the point D represents

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Solve the equation $z3=1$, giving your answers in Cartesian form.
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$z3z3​=1=cos0+isin0​$$$
Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z​=(cos0+isin0)31​=cos(32kπ​)+isin(32kπ​)[for k=0,1,2]​$$$
Hence the roots of the equation $z3=1$ are
$$$k=0k=1k=2​:z=cos0+isin0=1​:z=cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)=−21​+23​​i​:z=cos(34π​)+isin(34π​)=−21​−23​​i​​$$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A circle of radius 3 and centre (0,3) is drawn on an Argand diagram. The tangent to
the circle from the point B$(0,9)$ meets the circle at the point A as
shown. Let $w=OA$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04bae060-5e07-43ac-8364-cfc8cd354822/images/e865f15b-927e-4ac3-83c8-71f1486f972f/756bc10d49856365edc8188e18631d432452e02d.svg)




Show that $∣w∣=33​$. [2]



Find $argw$. [2]



Hence write $w$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$. [2]
list.markScheme:
Given that the angle between a tangent and a radius is a right angle, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04bae060-5e07-43ac-8364-cfc8cd354822/images/c4a50bb7-b50d-4dd2-a81a-400c65a24109/e572903f13ea5ca7d33e50badc186e738f21ec73.svg)


Using the right triangle ABC, we find
$$$cos(ACˆB)ACˆBACˆO​=63​(=21​)=3π​=32π​​$$$
Hence, using the
cosine rule, we get
$$$∣w∣2∣w∣2∣w∣2​=32+32−2(3)(3)cos(32π​)=18−18[−21​]=27​$$$
$$$∣w∣=33​​​$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04bae060-5e07-43ac-8364-cfc8cd354822/images/0be7156c-9e85-4803-88bb-febc8c38dfed/c956da10fdd9a0dd23ce23a1defc574f970f2c67.svg)




Using the isosceles triangle OAC, we have
$$$AOˆC​=21​(π−ACˆO)=21​[π−32π​]=6π​​$$$
Hence the argument of $w$ is
$$$argw​=2π​−AOˆC=2π​−6π​=3π​​​$$$


If we write $w$ in Cartesian form, we obtain
$$$w​=33​cis(3π​)=33​[cos(3π​)+isin(3π​)]=33​[21​+i23​​]=233​​+29​i​​$$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
In this question give all angles in radians.
Let $z=1+2i$ and
$w=4+i$.


Find $z+w$. [1]



Find:


$∣z+w∣$;


$arg(z+w)$. [3]





Find $θ$, the angle shown on the diagram below. [2]



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f0968bc-fcf5-46b9-9ca5-4e6c802b5585/images/e5aae188-d040-41e8-b169-2d50a1a756f5/9f1b9b167af97e4b2c9ee84b7c9014f2cdaf63c7.svg)

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Consider the complex number $z=w2​w1​​$ where
$w1​=2​+6​i$ and
$w2​=3+3​i$.


Express $w1​$ and $w2​$ in modulus-argument form and write down


the modulus of $z$;


the argument of $z$. [4]





Find the smallest positive integer value of $n$ such that $zn$ is a
real number. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we express $w1​$ and $w2​$ in modulus-argument form, we have
$$$w1​=22​cis(3π​)​andw2​=23​cis(6π​)​​$$$


Hence the modulus of $z$ is
$$$∣z∣​=∣w2​∣∣w1​∣​=2​3​2​2​​=36​​​​$$$


Hence the argument of $z$ is
$$$argz​=argw1​−argw2​=3π​−6π​=6π​​​$$$




The $n$th power of $z$ is a real number if
$$$sin(arg(zn))sin(nargz)sin(6nπ​)​=0=0[by de Moivre’s theorem]=0[by part (a) (ii)]​$$$
Hence the smallest $n∈Z+$ such that $zn$ is a real
number is  $n=6​$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Let $z=2+i$ and
$w=1−2i$.


Find $zw$. [2]



Illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram. [3]



Let $θ$ be the angle between $zw$ and $w$. Find $θ$,
giving your answer in radians.[3]
list.markScheme:
The product of $z$ and $w$ is
$$$zw​=(2+i)(1−2i)=2−4i+i+2=4−3i​​$$$


If we illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram, we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d16706e0-5faa-41a5-804d-8aaa9391a8e7/images/ed6df27d-739a-4366-8e0a-514cde709407/96f14dbc4defd6873946ae02a45c2e643f791342.svg)




We have
$$$argw​=tan−1((−2)/1)=−1.107148…​$$$
and
$$$argzw​=tan−1((−3)/4)=−0.643501…​$$$
Hence we get
$$$θ​=∣argw∣−∣argzw∣=(1.107148…)−(0.643501…)≈0.464​​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Let $z=rei6π​$ where
$r∈R+$.


For $r=3​$,


express $z2$ and $z3$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$;


draw $z2$ and $z3$ on the following Argand diagram.
[4]



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/25f0d8f7-978f-4d4f-985d-c76b02b32a2c/images/9d23235e-6a7d-47d4-bc54-39e966a1c5c6/633c15de281dbaeb852d4279b825abc3a94854e8.svg)






Given that the integer powers of
$w=6+2iz​$ lie on a
unit circle centred
at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we express $z2$ and $z3$ in Cartesian form, we get
$$$z2​=3ei3π​=3[cos(3π​)+isin(3π​)]=23​+233​​i​​$$$
and
$$$z3​=33​ei2π​=33​[cos(2π​)+isin(2π​)]=0+33​i​​$$$


If we draw $z2$ and $z3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/25f0d8f7-978f-4d4f-985d-c76b02b32a2c/images/ecfbb324-4335-4248-af17-503361e08908/ecdfaa8e1f1031e684d45d25638e79596842fb1a.svg)






We have
$$$∣6+2i∣​=62+22​=40​=210​​$$$
Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find
$$$∣wk∣∣w∣k∣w∣​6+2iz​​∣6+2i∣∣z∣​210​r​​=1[for all k∈Z]=1=1=1[w=z/(6+2i)]=1=1​$$$
$$$r=210​​$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Consider the equation $5−z∗3z​=i$, where
$z=x+iy$ and $x$, $y∈R$.
Find the value of $x$ and the value of $y$.
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$5−z∗3z​5−(x−iy)3(x+iy)​5−x+yi3x+3yi​3x+3yi3x+3yi3x+3yi​=i=i=i=i(5−x+yi)=5i−xi−y=−y+(5−x)i​$$$
Complex numbers can be
equal only if their real and imaginary parts are equal.
Equating the real
parts, we get
$$$3xy​=−y=−3x(1)​$$$
Equating the imaginary parts, we get
$$$3y3(−3x)−9x​=5−x=5−x[by equation (1)]=5−xx=−85​​​$$$
Substituting the value of $x$ in equation $(1)$, we get
$$$y​=−3(−85​)y=815​​​$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $z=rei3π​$ where
$r∈R+$.


For $r=2​$,


express $z2$ and $z3$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$;


draw $z2$ and $z3$ on the following Argand diagram.
[4]



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59a008f3-3d50-44d9-869a-42b4824709d2/images/9f941692-8f3e-4cfd-9d12-fc50abaa27ce/7e711daec273ec9c0f630b852aae229a5a09d558.svg)






Given that the integer powers of
$w=(3−3i)z$ lie
on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$.
[2]
list.markScheme:
If we express $z2$ and $z3$ in Cartesian form, we get
$$$z2​=2ei32π​=2[cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)]=−1+3​i​​$$$
and
$$$z3​=22​eiπ=22​[cosπ+isinπ]=−22​+0i​​$$$


If we draw $z2$ and $z3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59a008f3-3d50-44d9-869a-42b4824709d2/images/b1595772-f8bb-4154-802a-3fe48a2a9de8/ee3e2d0e8670f88c39e4d0221f05849bcdba3ebd.svg)






We have
$$$∣3−3i∣​=32+(−3)2​=18​=32​​$$$
Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find
$$$∣wk∣∣w∣k∣w∣∣(3−3i)z∣∣3−3i∣∣z∣32​r​=1[for all k∈Z]=1=1=1[w=(3−3i)z]=1=1​$$$
$$$r=62​​​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The complex numbers $z$ and $w$ correspond to the points A and B as
shown on the diagram below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9662101a-846e-4330-acd8-a3cb1cce180f/images/03879786-889a-461a-8062-d630c448493e/0c46fa70e78de8ef6fa11a8d28566cc1742d4a83.svg)




Find the exact value of $∣z−w∣$. [2]





Find the exact perimeter of triangle AOB.


Find the exact area of triangle AOB. [4]
list.markScheme:
Using the cosine rule, we get
$$$∣z−w∣2∣z−w∣2∣z−w∣2​=∣z∣2+∣w∣2−2∣z∣∣w∣cos(6π​)=52+52−2(5)(5)[23​​]=25(2−3​)​$$$
$$$∣z−w∣=52−3​​​$$$




The exact perimeter of triangle AOB is
$$$perimeter​=∣z∣+∣w∣+∣z−w∣=5+5+52−3​​=10+52−3​​​​$$$


The exact area of triangle AOB is
$$$area​=21​∣z∣∣w∣sin(6π​)=21​(5)(5)[21​]=425​​​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
The complex numbers $w$ and $z$ satisfy the equations
$$$wz​w∗+2z​=i,=4+5i.​$$$
Find $w$ and $z$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈Z$.
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$z=iw$$$
and
$$$w∗+2z=4+5i(1)$$$
Substituting $w=x+yi$ and
$z=i(x+yi)$
in the equation $(1)$, we have
$$$(x+yi)∗+2i(x+yi)(x−yi)+(−2y+2xi)(x−2y)+(2x−y)i​=4+5i=4+5i=4+5i(2)​$$$
Hence, comparing real and imaginary parts of the equation $(2)$, we get
$$$x−2y2x−y​==​45​(3)$$$
Solving the system of equations
$(3)$ for $x$ and $y$, we obtain $x=2$ and $y=−1$.
Hence we find
$w=2−i​$
and
$z=1+2i​$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $z=2cis2θ$ where $0<θ<45°$.
Find the modulus and argument of $z+2$, expressing your answers in
terms of $θ$.
list.markScheme:
Illustrating $z$ and $z+2$ on an Argand diagram, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2858c999-8929-4209-afa2-7ea545cdabda/images/d155a6b0-9910-4f8e-8bd8-2a74632b9757/1d7aa7a6ad70d5559224e1ad164664c7c8b18e90.svg)


Since $OA=AB=BC=OC=2$, the
shape OABC is a rhombus.
Letting M be the midpoint of OB, we further have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2858c999-8929-4209-afa2-7ea545cdabda/images/f8e9ec25-1e0b-4926-b43f-13f07786902e/ab69dba55452ae052577c8e1dbf5234f80b40234.svg)


Since OB bisects the angle AOC, we have
$$$arg(z+2)arg(z+2)​=21​argz=21​(2θ)​$$$
$$$arg(z+2)=θ​​$$$
Using
the right triangle AOM, we have
$$$cosθOMOB​=∣z∣OM​=2cosθ[since ∣z∣=2]=4cosθ[since M is a midpoint]​$$$
$$$∣z+2∣=4cosθ​$$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Let $w=2ei32π​$.




Write $w$, $w2$ and $w3$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$.


Draw $w$, $w2$ and $w3$ on an Argand diagram. [6]





Find the smallest integer $k>3$ such that $wk$ is a real number.
[2]
list.markScheme:
If we write $w$, $w2$, and $w3$ in Rectangular form, we get
$$$ww2w3​=2ei32π​=2[cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)]=−1+3​i​=4ei34π​=4[cos(34π​)+isin(34π​)]=−2−23​i​=8ei2π=8[cos2π+isin2π]=8+0i​​$$$


If we draw $w$, $w2$ and $w3$ on an Argand diagram, we obtain


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/74730608-0b90-45f7-ab9d-7f250902cd9f/images/088fe83f-a3ad-423f-aa34-b1c36029c906/9359549edafb8a3552c9584a8d94ff3edead064e.svg)






We have
$$$arg(wk)​=32kπ​​$$$
The $k$th
power of $w$ is real if $arg(wk)$ is a multiple of $π$.
Hence the smallest such integer $k>3$ is
$k=6​$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Consider the equation $z4−6z3+cz2−30z+13=0$ where $z∈C$ and $c∈R$.
Three of the roots of the equation are $2−3i$, $α$ and $α4$, where $α∈R$.


Find the value of $α$.[4]



Hence, or otherwise, find the value of $c$.[3]
list.markScheme:
Since $2−3i$ is a root its conjugate $2+3i$ is a root too.
Now, using the formula for the product of the roots, we get
$$$product of roots(2−3i)⋅(2+3i)⋅α⋅α413⋅α5​=(−1)4a4​a0​​=(1)113​=13α=1​[since α∈R]​$$$


The complex polynomial can be factorised as
$$$p(x)​=(x−(2+3i))(x−(2−3i))(x−1)(x−1)=(x2−4x+13)(x−1)2=(x2−4x+13)(x2−2x+1)=x4−6x3+22x2−30x+13​$$$
Therefore, we conclude that $c=22​$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Find three distinct roots of the equation $z3+64=0$,
$z∈C$, giving your answers in modulus-argument form.
[6]



The roots are represented by the vertices of a triangle in an Argand
diagram.

Show that the area of the triangle is $123​$.
[3]
list.markScheme:
Using the equality
$−1=cosπ+isinπ$, we
have
$$$z3​=−64=64(cosπ+isinπ)​$$$
Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z​=6431​(cosπ+isinπ)31​=4[cos(3π+2kπ​)+isin(3π+2kπ​)]​$$$
for $k=0,1,2$.
Hence the roots of the equation $z3=−64$ are
$$$k=0k=1k=2​:z=4[cos(3π​)+isin(3π​)]​:z=4[cosπ+isinπ]​(1):z=4[cos(35π​)+isin(35π​)]​​$$$


If we sketch the triangle whose vertices represent the roots $(1)$
on an Argand diagram, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9fa44e69-114c-4fc2-8ed7-41de6d959b17/images/30051166-b0d5-4036-8425-d098792614af/7ba8fa24617bc7505a9ecf65b0f77c82f33a610b.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is
$$$Area​=3[21​(4)(4)sin(32π​)]=3[21​(4)(4)(23​​)]=123​​​$$$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Consider the complex numbers
$u=1+2i$ and
$v=2+i$.


Given that $u1​+v1​=w62​​$,
express $w$ in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$.  [4]



Find $w∗$ and express it in the form
$reiθ$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $u=1+2i$ and
$v=2+i$ in the given equation,
we have
$$$w62​​​=u1​+v1​=1+2i1​+2+i1​=1+2i1​⋅1−2i1−2i​+2+i1​⋅2−i2−i​=51−2i​+52−i​=53−3i​(1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $w$, we get
$$$w​=3−3i302​​=1−i102​​⋅1+i1+i​=2102​(1+i)​=52​(1+i)=52​+52​i​​$$$


The conjugate of $w$ is
$$$w∗​=52​−52​i=10[22​​−22​​i]=10[cos(4π​)−isin(4π​)]=10[cos(−4π​)+isin(−4π​)]=10e−i4π​​[by Euler’s formula]​$$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Consider the complex conjugates $z$ and $z∗$.

Show that $(x−z)(x−z∗)=x2−2Re(z)x+∣z∣2$. [3]


$z1​$ and $z2​$ are two of the roots of the real polynomial $z4+az3+bz2+cz+d$. Where $a,b,c,d∈Q$.

If $z1​=2​cis4π​$ and $z2​=2−i$ hence, or otherwise, find the values of $a,b,c$ and $d$. [4]

$sinx$
list.markScheme:
Expand the expression
$$$(x−z)(x−z∗)​=x2−zx−z∗x+zz∗=x2−(z+z∗)x+zz∗​(M1)​$$$
If we let $z=a+bi$ then $z∗=a−bi$.
We can now simplify $z+z∗$ and $zz∗$.
$$$z+z∗zz∗​=a+bi+a−bi=2a=2Re(z)=(a+bi)(a−bi)=a2−b2i2=a2+b2=∣z∣2​A1A1​$$$
Substituting these expressions into the expansion above we get
$$$(x−z)(x−z∗)​=x2−(z+z∗)x+zz∗=x2−2Re(z)x+∣z∣2​... as required.​$$$


Recognise that a real polynomial has complex roots in  conjugate pairs.
We can write the remaining roots of the polynomial
$$$z3​=z1∗​​=2​cis4−π​​​z4​=z2∗​=2+i​$$$
We can now write the polynomial in factorised form using the roots
$$$z4+az3+bz2+cz+d​=(z−z1​)(z−z2​)(z−z3​)(z−z4​)=(z−z1​)(z−z1∗​)(z−z2​)(z−z2∗​)​$$$
We can use the identity we proved part(a) to rewrite the factors
$$$(z−z1​)(z−z1∗​)(z−z2​)(z−z2∗​)​=(z2−2Re(z1​)z+∣z1​∣2)(z2−2Re(z2​)z+∣z2​∣2)​$$$
$$$hack​(M1)​$$$
Next we can identify the elements we need complete the expansion
$$$Re(z1​)Re(z1​)Re(z1​)Re(z2​)Re(z2​)​=2​×cos4π​=2​×22​​=1=2​​∣z1​∣2=2​2∣z1​∣2=2∣z2​∣2=(22+12​)2∣z2​∣2=5​A1A1​$$$
We can now substitute these values into the expansion above
$$$​(z2−2Re(z1​)z+∣z1​∣2)(z2−2Re(z2​)z+∣z2​∣2)=(z2−2×1z+2)(z2−2×2z+5)​$$$
We can now expand this expression and simplify
$$$​(z2−2z+2)(z2−4z+5)=z4−4z3+5z2−2z3+8z2−10z+2z2−8z+10=z4−6z3+15z2−18z+10​$$$
$Therefore a=−6,b=15,c=−18 and d=10​$
$$$hack​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Consider the equation $2z4+az3+bz2+cz+d=0$, where
$a,b,c,d∈R$ and $z∈C$. Two of the roots of
the equation are $log2​10$ and
$i5​$ and the sum of all the
roots is $4+log2​5$.
Show that $15a+d+90=0$.
list.markScheme:
Since $i5​$ is a root, its
conjugate $−i5​$ is also a
root of the equation.
If $z4​$ is the fourth root of the equation, we have
$$$i5​​+(−i5​​)+log2​10+z4​z4​z4​z4​z4​​=4+log2​5[sum of roots]=4+log2​5−log2​10=4+log2​5​−(log2​2+log2​5​)=4−1[since log2​2=1]=3​$$$
Using Vieta's formulas, we have
$$$−2a​a​=4+log2​5[sum of roots]=−8−2log2​5​$$$
and
$$$(−1)4[2d​]d​=(i5​)(−i5​)(log2​10)(3)[product of roots]=30log2​10​$$$
Hence we get
$$$15a+d+90​=15(−8−2log2​5)+30log2​10+90=−120−30log2​5​+30log2​2+30log2​5​+90=−120+30+90[since log2​2=1]=0​​$$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Express $−4+43​i$ in the
form $reiθ$, where
$r>0$ and $−π<θ≤π$. [5]



Let the roots of the equation
$z3=−4+43​i$ be $z1​$,
$z2​$ and $z3​$.


Find $z1​$, $z2​$ and $z3​$ expressing your answers in the
form $reiθ$, where
$r>0$ and $−π<θ≤π$. [5]



On an Argand diagram, $z1​$, $z2​$ and $z3​$ are represented by the
points A, B and C, respectively.


Find the area of the triangle ABC. [4]



By considering the sum of the roots $z1​$, $z2​$ and $z3​$,
show that
$$$cos(92π​)+cos(94π​)+cos(98π​)=0$$$
[4]
list.markScheme:
If we express $−4+43​i$
in the form $reiθ$, we
have
$$$−4+43​i​=8[−21​+23​​i]=8[cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)]=8ei32π​​[by Euler’s formula]​$$$


Using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z​=38​[cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)]31​​$$$
$$$​=38​[cos(32π/3+2kπ​)+isin(32π/3+2kπ​)]=2[cos(92π​+32kπ​)+isin(92π​+32kπ​)]=2ei(92π​+32kπ​)[by Euler’s formula]​$$$
for $k=−1,0,1$.
Hence the roots of the equation
$z3=−4+43​i$ are
$$$z1​=2e−i94π​,z2​=2ei92π​,z3​=2ei98π​​​$$$


If we sketch the triangle ABC on an Argand diagram, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4972dc2f-d75c-4381-9bb4-fc54b532136b/images/954bc9f2-f844-4032-afcd-9d9769dcfa66/be310f824ce127a4f24f53c5e5e7cb15aa1f5774.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is
$$$Area​=3[21​(2)(2)sin(32π​)]=3[21​(2)(2)(23​​)]=33​​​$$$


The sum of the roots of the equation
$z3=−4+43​i$ is zero.
Hence we have
$$$Re(z1​+z2​+z3​)cos(−94π​)+cos(92π​)+cos(98π​)​=0=0​$$$
$$$cos(92π​)+cos(94π​)+cos(98π​)=0​$$$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
Consider the real polynomial
$$$p(z)=2z3+az2+bz−75​$$$
One of the roots of $p(z)$ is $3+4i$.


Find the remaining roots of $p(z)$.[4]



Hence determine the values of $a$ and $b$.[3]
list.markScheme:
We know, due to the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, that a polynomial of order $3$ must have $3$ roots.
Also, $p(z)$ is a real polynomial, this means its coefficients are real numbers and that any complex roots must come in conjugate pairs.
Hence we can write down the second root as $3−4i​$.
$$$placeholder​A1​$$$
We have one root remaining, it must be real.
Looking at the polynomial we can see we have been given the first and last coefficient.
Consider the formulae for the sum and products of the roots of a polynomial
$$$Sum of roots​=an​−an−1​​Product of roots=an​(−1)na0​​​$$$
$n$ is the order of the polynomial, which in this case is $3$.
$an​$, where $n=3$ refers to the coefficient of the $z3$ term and $a0​$ refers to the constant term.
We can write down the values
$$$a3​a0​​=2=−75​(M1)​$$$
This is enough information to find the value of the product of the roots.
Hence
$$$Product of roots​=an​(−1)na0​​=2(−1)3×(−75)​=275​​A1​$$$
If we call the third root $z3​$ we can form an equation which we can solve on our G.D.C.
$$$(3+4i)(3−4i)z3​z3​​=275​=23​​​A1​$$$


We can use the roots from part (a) to write out $p(z)$ in factorised form
$$$(z−(3+4i))(z−(3−4i)(z−23​)(z−3−4i)(z−3+4i)(z−23​)​=0=0​(M1)​$$$
There is a very useful identity, worth memorising, that is helpful when expanding brackets of $this$ form
$$$(z−w)(z−w∗)​=z2−2Re(w)(z)+∣w∣2​$$$
In our case $w=3+4i$ therefore
$$$∣w∣2​=(32+42​)2=52=25​$$$
And
$$$Re(w)​=Re(3+4i)=3​$$$
Putting these results together we can expand the $red$ part of the factorised form to get
$$$(z−3−4i)(z−3+4i)(z−23​)(z2−2×3z+25)(z−23​)​=0=0​A1​$$$
Now we can expand the rest of the expression to get
$$$z3−6z2+25z−23​z2+9z−275​​=0​$$$
We can multiply throughout by $2$ and simplify to get
$$$2z3−12z2+50z−3z2+18z−752x3−15z2+68z−75p(z)=2x3−15z2+68z−75​=0=0​$$$
Therefore $a=−15​$ and $b=68​$.
$$$placeholder​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Consider the complex numbers $z1​=3cis(120°)$
and $z2​=2+2i$.


Calculate $z2​z1​​$ giving your answer both in
modulus-argument form and
Cartesian form. [7]



Use your results from part (a) to find the exact value of
$sin15°⋅sin45°⋅sin75°$,
giving your answer in the form $ba​​$ where
$a,b∈Z+$. [5]
list.markScheme:
If we express $z1​$ in Cartesian form, we have
$$$z1​​=3cis(120°)=3cos(120°)+3isin(120°)=−23​+233​i​=23​(−1+3​i)​$$$
If we express $z2​$ in modulus-argument form, we have
$$$z2​​=2+2i=2(1+i)=22​(cos(45°)+isin(45°))=22​cis(45°)​$$$
Hence, if we calculate $z2​z1​​$ giving answer in
modulus-argument form, we get
$$$z2​z1​​​=22​cis(45°)3cis(120°)​=432​​cis(75°)​​$$$
Hence, if we calculate $z2​z1​​$ giving answer in Cartesian
form, we obtain
$$$z2​z1​​​=2+2i23​(−1+3​i)​=2+2i23​(−1+3​i)​⋅2−2i2−2i​=(2+2i)(2−2i)3(−1+3​i)(1−i)​=4+4−3+3i+33​i+33​​=83(3​−1)​+83(3​+1)​i​​$$$


If we equate the two expressions for $z2​z1​​$ from part
(a), we have
$$$432​​cos(75°)+432​​isin(75°)​=83(3​−1)​+83(3​+1)​i​$$$
Hence we get
$$$cos75°​=32​4​⋅83(3​−1)​=22​3​−1​​$$$
and
$$$sin75°​=32​4​⋅83(3​+1)​=22​3​+1​​$$$
Hence we find
$$$sin15°⋅sin45°⋅sin75°​=cos75°⋅sin45°⋅sin75°=22​3​−1​⋅22​​⋅22​3​+1​=16(3−1)2​​=82​​​​$$$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Consider $w=z+iz−1​$
where $z=x+iy$ and
$i=−1​$.


If $z=i$,


write $w$ in the form $rcisθ$;


find the value of $w14$. [5]





Show that in general,
$$$w=x2+(y+1)2(x2−x+y2+y)+i(y−x+1)​$$$
[4]



Find condition under which $Re(w)=1$. [2]



State condition under which $w$ is:


real;


purely imaginary. [2]





Find the modulus of $z$ given that $argw=4π​$.
[2]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $z=i$ in the
expression for $w$, we have
$$$w​=i+ii−1​=2ii−1​⋅−i−i​=21+i​=21​+21​i(1)​$$$
Hence, if we express $w$ given by $(1)$ in modulus-argument
form, we get
$$$w​=21​+21​i=2​1​[22​​+22​​i]=2​1​[cos(4π​)+isin(4π​)]=2​1​cis(4π​)​​$$$


Using de Moivre's theorem, we obtain
$$$w14​=[2​1​cis(4π​)]14=271​cis(27π​)=1281​(−i)=−128i​​​$$$




Substituting $z=x+iy$ in the
expression for $w$, we have
$$$w​=(x+iy)+i(x+iy)−1​=x+i(y+1)(x−1)+iy​⋅x−i(y+1)x−i(y+1)​=x2+(y+1)2x(x−1)+y(y+1)+i[xy−(x−1)(y+1)]​=x2+(y+1)2(x2−x)+(y2+y)+i[xy​−xy​−x+y+1]​=x2+(y+1)2(x2−x+y2+y)+i(y−x+1)​​[(x,y)=(0,−1)](2)​$$$


Hence $Re(w)=1$ if
$$$x2+(y+1)2x2−x+y2+y​x2−x+y2+yx2−x+y2+y−x​=1[by (2)]=x2+(y+1)2=x2+y2+2y+1=y+1​$$$
$$$y=−x−1​[(x,y)=(0,−1)]$$$




$w$ is real if
$y−x+1=0​$
where $(x,y)=(0,−1)$.


$w$ is purely imaginary if
$x2−x+y2+y=0 and y−x+1=0​$




Given that $argw=4π​$, we have
$$$tan(argw)1x2−x+y2+yx2+y2x2+y2​​=x2−x+y2+yy−x+1​=x2−x+y2+yy−x+1​=y−x+1=1=1​$$$
$$$∣z∣=1​$$$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
On an Argand diagram, the complex numbers
$z1​=2+23​i$,
$z2​=1−i$ and $z3​=z1​z2​$ are
represented by the vertices of a triangle.
The exact area of the triangle can be expressed in the form
$p+q​$. Find the value of $p$ and of $q$.
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$∣z1​∣∣z2​∣​=22+(23​)2​=4=12+(−1)2​=2​​$$$
and
$$$argz1​argz2​​=tan−1(23​/2)=60°=tan−1(−1/1)=−45°​$$$
Hence, using the property of modulus, we get
$$$∣z3​∣​=∣z1​z2​∣=∣z1​∣∣z2​∣=42​​$$$
and
$$$argz3​​=arg(z1​z2​)=argz1​+argz2​=15°​$$$
If we sketch the triangle whose vertices represent $z1​$, $z2​$ and
$z3​$ on an Argand diagram, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d725016-9066-4b8c-ac95-c47814030441/images/d6a47e5a-26b2-4956-8144-2fd2e75f4f4d/e1e467a933ff283d4afc5581ecd27d102258be6b.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is
$$$area(ABˆC)​=area(AOˆC)+area(BOˆC)−area(AOˆB)=21​(4)(42​)sin45°+21​(2​)(42​)sin60°−21​(4)(2​)sin(60°+45°)=(82​)(2​1​)+4(23​​)−22​(sin(60°)cos(45°)+cos(60°)sin(45°))=8+23​−22​(23​​2​1​+21​2​1​)=7+3​​$$$
Therefore,
$p=7​$and$q=3​$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Find three distinct roots of the equation $z3+27i=0$, $z∈C$, giving your answers in exact cartesian form. [3]


Let $w$ be the sum of two of the roots of $z$, from part (a), which have non-zero real parts and $c+wc​=2i$.

Show that $c=56​+512​i$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z3+27iz3zzk​​=0=−27i=2731​(cos23π​+isin23π​)31​=3(cos33π/2+2kπ​+isin33π/2+2kπ​)​M1​$$$
for $k=0,1,2$.
Hence the roots of the equation $z3+27i=0$ are
$$$z0​z1​z2​​=3(cos2π​+isin2π​)=3(cos67π​+isin67π​)=3(cos611π​+isin611π​)​A1​$$$
Converting the roots to its Cartesian form, we obtain
$$$k=0:z0​=3i​k=1:z1​=−233​​−23i​​k=2:z2​=233​​−23i​​​A1​$$$


First, the sum of the roots described is
$$$w​=z1​+z2​=−3i​A1​$$$
Working out the complex equation, we get
$$$c+wc​ccc−2icc(1−2i)ccc​=2i=2i(c−3i)=2ic+6=6=6=1−2i6​=1−2i6​⋅1+2i1+2i​=1+46+12i​z=56​+512​i​...as required​M1M1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
Let
$z=cosθ+isinθ$,
for $−4π​<θ<4π​$.




Find $z3$ using the binomial theorem.


Use de Moivre's theorem to show that
$cos3θ=4cos3θ−3cosθ$ and
$sin3θ=3sinθ−4sin3θ$. [8]





Hence show that
$cos3θ+cosθsin3θ−sinθ​=tanθ$.
[6]



Given that $sinθ=31​$, find the exact value of
$tan3θ$. [5]
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we get
$$$z3​=(cosθ+isinθ)3=cos3θ+3cos2θ(isinθ)+3cosθ(isinθ)2+(isinθ)3=cos3θ+3icos2θsinθ−3cosθsin2θ−isin3θ=(cos3θ−3cosθsin2θ)+i(3cos2θsinθ−sin3θ)​​$$$


Using de Moivre's theorem, we have
$$$z3​=(cosθ+isinθ)3=cos3θ+isin3θ​$$$
Hence, using part (a) (i), we obtain
$$$cos3θcos3θ​=cos3θ−3cosθsin2θ[=Re(z3)]=cos3θ−3cosθ(1−cos2θ)​$$$
$$$cos3θ=4cos3θ−3cosθ​(1)$$$
and
$$$sin3θsin3θ​=3cos2θsinθ−sin3θ[=Im(z3)]=3(1−sin2θ)sinθ−sin3θ​$$$
$$$sin3θ=3sinθ−4sin3θ​(2)$$$




Hence, using the identities $(1)$ & $(2)$ from part (a) (ii), we
deduce
$$$cos3θ+cosθsin3θ−sinθ​​=(4cos3θ−3cosθ)+cosθ(3sinθ−4sin3θ)−sinθ​=4cos3θ−2cosθ2sinθ−4sin3θ​=2cosθ(2cos2θ−1)2sinθ(1−2sin2θ)​=2​cosθcos2θ2​sinθcos2θ​=cosθsinθ​=tanθ​​$$$


Given that $sinθ=31​$, for
$0<θ<4π​$, we have
$$$cosθ​=322​​​$$$
Hence, using the identities $(1)$ & $(2)$ from part (a) (ii), we
find
$$$tan3θ​=cos3θsin3θ​=4cos3θ−3cosθ3sinθ−4sin3θ​=4(22​/3)3−3(22​/3)3(1/3)−4(1/3)3​=642​/27−22​1−4/27​=642​−542​27−4​=102​23​=20232​​​​$$$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Expand
$(cosθ+isinθ)4$
by using the binomial theorem.


Hence use de Moivre's theorem to prove that
$$$cos4θ=cos4θ−6cos2θsin2θ+sin4θ.​$$$


State a similar expression for $sin4θ$ in terms of
$cosθ$ and $sinθ$. [6]





Let
$z=r(cosα+isinα)$,
where $α$ is measured in degrees, be the solution
of $z4−i=0$ which has the
smallest positive argument.


Find the modulus and argument of $z$.
[4]



Use (a) (ii) and your answer from (b) to show that
$8cos4α−8cos2α+1=0$.  [4]



Hence express $cos22.5°$ in the form
$da+bc​​​$ where $a,b,c,d∈Z$.
[5]
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$​(cosθ+isinθ)4=cos4θ+4icos3θsinθ−6cos2θsin2θ−4icosθsin3θ+sin4θ​(1)​$$$


Using de Moivre's theorem, we have
$$$(cosθ+isinθ)4=cos4θ+isin4θ(2)​$$$
Hence, if we compare real parts of the expressions $(1)$ and
$(2)$, we deduce
$$$cos4θ=cos4θ−6cos2θsin2θ+sin4θ​(3)​$$$


If we compare imaginary parts of the expressions $(1)$ and
$(2)$, we obtain
$$$sin4θ=4cos3θsinθ−4cosθsin3θ​​$$$




Using de Moivre's theorem, we have
$$$z4−iz4z4z​=0=i=cis(2π​)=cis(8π​+2kπ​)[for k=0,1,2,3]​$$$
Hence the modulus of $z$ is
$$$r=1​​$$$
and the argument of $z$ is
$$$α=8π​=22.5°​​$$$


Substituting $θ=α$ in the equation $(3)$, we get
$$$cos4α−6cos2αsin2α+sin4αcos4α−6cos2α(1−cos2α)+(1−cos2α)2cos4α−(6cos2α−6cos4α)+(1−2cos2α+cos4α)​=cos4α=cos90°=0​$$$
$$$8cos4α−8cos2α+1=0​(4)$$$


Hence, using the quadratic formula to solve the
equation $(4)$ for $cos2α$, we have
$$$cos2αcos2α∣cosα∣​=2(8)−(−8)±(−8)2−4(8)(1)​​=42±2​​=22±2​​​​$$$
We have
$$$cos22.5°>cos45°=22​​>0(5)​$$$
Hence, using the inequalities $(5)$, we obtain
$$$cos22.5°=22+2​​​​​$$$

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
Solve $2sin(x+120°)=3​cos(x+60°)$, for
$x∈[0,180°]$.  [5]



Show that $sin75°+cos75°=26​​$.
[3]



Let
$z=sin4θ+i(1−cos4θ)$,
for $z∈C$, $θ∈[0,90°]$.


Find the modulus and argument of $z$ in terms of $θ$.


Hence find the fourth roots of $z$ in modulus-argument form.
[14]
list.markScheme:
Using the compound angle formulas for sine and cosine, we find
$$$2sin(x+120°)2(sinxcos120°+cosxsin120°)2sinx(−sin30°)+2cosxcos30°2sinx(−21​)+2cosx(23​​)−2sinx+23​cosxsinxtanx​=3​cos(x+60°)=3​(cosxcos60°−sinxsin60°)=3​cosxcos60°−3​sinxsin60°=3​cosx(21​)−3​sinx(23​​)=3​cosx−3sinx=−3​cosx=−3​​$$$
$$$x=120°​$$$


Using the compound angle formula for sine, we get
$$$(sin75°+cos75°)2​=(sin75°)2+(cos75°)2+2sin75°cos75°=1+sin(75°+75°)=1+cos60°=1+21​=46​(1)​$$$
Hence, if we take the
square root of both sides of the equality $(1)$, we obtain
$$$sin75°+cos75°=26​​​​$$$




The modulus of $z$ is
$$$∣z∣​=[(sin4θ)2+(1−cos4θ)2]21​=[(sin4θ)2+(cos4θ)2+1−2cos4θ]21​=[2−2cos4θ]21​=[2(1−cos4θ)]21​=[2(1−(1−2(sin2θ)2)]21​[by double-angle formula]=[4(sin2θ)2]21​=2∣sin2θ∣=2sin2θ​[since sin2θ≥0 for θ∈[0,90°]]​$$$
Using the double-angle formulas for sine and cosine, we have
$$$tan(argz)​=sin4θ1−cos4θ​=2sin2θcos2θ1−[1−2(sin2θ)2]​=cos2θsin2θ​=tan2θ​$$$
Hence the argument of $z$ is
$argz=2θ​$


Hence, using part (c) and de Moivre's theorem, we find
$$$z41​​=(2sin2θcis2θ)41​=42sin2θ​cis(42θ+2kπ​)=42sin2θ​cis(2θ+kπ​)​​$$$
for $k=0,1,2,3$.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
Find the roots of $z16=1$ which satisfy the condition
$0<arg(z)<2π​$,
expressing your answer in the form
$reiθ$, where
$r,θ∈R+$. [5]



Let $S$ be the sum of the roots found in part (a).


Show that $Re(S)=Im(S)$.


By writing $8π​$ as
$21​⋅4π​$, find the value of
$cos(8π​)$ in the form
$ca+b​​​$,
where $a,b$ and $c$ are integers to be determined.


Hence, or otherwise, show that
$S=21​(2+2​​+2​+2−2​​)(1+i)$.
[11]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$z16z16​=1=cos0+isin0​$$$
Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z​=(cos0+isin0)161​=cos(162kπ​)+isin(162kπ​)=cos(8kπ​)+isin(8kπ​)=ei8kπ​[by Euler’s formula]​$$$
for $k=0,1,2,…,15$.
Hence the roots of the equation $z16=1$ that satisfy
$0<arg(z)<2π​$ are
$$$k=1k=2k=3​:z1​=ei8π​​:z2​=ei4π​​:z3​=ei83π​​​$$$




If we let $S=z1​+z2​+z3​$, we have
$$$Re(S)Im(S)​=cos(8π​)+cos(4π​)+cos(83π​)=sin(8π​)+sin(4π​)+sin(83π​)​$$$
Using the reflection law for cosine and sine, we get
$$$cos(8π​)cos(4π​)cos(83π​)​=cos(2π​−83π​)=sin(83π​)=cos(2π​−4π​)=sin(4π​)=cos(2π​−8π​)=sin(8π​)​$$$
Hence we deduce
$Re(S)=Im(S)​$


Using the half-angle formula for cosine, we have
$$$cos(8π​)​=cos(21​⋅4π​)=21+cos(π/4)​​=21​[1+22​​​]​=22+2​​​​​$$$


Similarly, using the half-angle formula for sine, we have
$$$cos(83π​)​=sin(8π​)=sin(21​⋅4π​)=21−cos(π/4)​​=21​[1−22​​​]​=22−2​​​​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$Re(S)​=cos(8π​)+cos(4π​)+cos(83π​)=22+2​​​+22​​+22−2​​​=21​(2+2​​+2​+2−2​​)​$$$
Hence we obtain
$$$S​=Re(S)+iIm(S)=Re(S)+iRe(S)[since Re(S)=Im(S)]=Re(S)(1+i)=21​(2+2​​+2​+2−2​​)(1+i)​​$$$

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
Solve the equation $z3=27$, $z∈C$, giving your
answer in the form
$z=r(cosθ+isinθ)$
and in the form $z=a+bi$
where $a,b∈R$.  [6]



Consider the complex numbers
$z1​=−1+i and z2​=2​1​[cos(3π​)+isin(3π​)]$
.


Write $z1​$ in the form
$r(cosθ+isinθ)$.


Calculate $z1​z2​$ and write in the form
$a+bi$ where
$a,b∈R$.


Hence find the value of $tan(12π​)$ in
the form $c+d3​$ where $c,d∈Z$.


Find the smallest $p∈Q+$ such that $(z1​z2​)p$ is
a positive real number. [11]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$z3​=27(cos0+isin0)​$$$
Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z​=2731​(cos0+isin0)31​=3[cos(32kπ​)+isin(32kπ​)][for k=0,1,2]​$$$
Hence the roots of the equation $z3=27$ are
$$$k=0k=1k=2​:z=3(cos0+isin0)=3​:z=3[cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)]=−23​+233​​i​:z=3[cos(34π​)+isin(34π​)]=−23​−233​​i​​$$$




If we write $z1​$ in modulus-argument form, we have
$$$z1​​=−1+i=2​[−22​​+22​​i]=2​[cos(43π​)+isin(43π​)]​​$$$


If we write $z2​$ in Cartesian form, we have
$$$z2​​=2​1​[cos(3π​)+isin(3π​)]=2​1​[21​+23​​i]=42​​+46​​i​$$$
Hence, if we calculate $z1​z2​$ giving answer in Cartesian form,
we obtain
$$$z1​z2​​=(−1+i)[42​​+46​​i]=−42​​−46​​i+42​​i−46​​=4−2​−6​​+42​−6​​i​(1)​$$$


If we calculate $z1​z2​$ giving answer in modulus-argument form,
we have
$$$z1​z2​​=[2​​cis(43π​)][2​​1​cis(3π​)]=cis(43π​+3π​)=cis(1213π​)=cos(1213π​)+isin(1213π​)(2)​$$$
Hence, comparing the expressions $(1)$ and $(2)$, we find
$$$cos(1213π​)sin(1213π​)​=4−2​−6​​=42​−6​​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$tan(12π​)​=tan(1213π​)=sin(1213π​)÷cos(1213π​)=4​2​−6​​⋅−2​−6​4​​=6​+2​6​−2​​⋅6​−2​6​−2​​=48−43​​=2−3​​​$$$


The $p$ th power of $z1​z2​$ is a real
number if
$$$sin(arg((z1​z2​)p))sin(parg(z1​z2​))sin(1213pπ​)​=0=0[by de Moivre’s theorem]=0[by part (b) (iii)]​$$$
Hence the smallest $p∈Q+$ such that $(z1​z2​)p$
is a positive real number is
$$$p=1324​​​$$$

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
In this question, you will use complex numbers to rewrite a trigonometric function into a different form. Then, you will use this function to model a cocktail glass.
Consider the complex number $z=cis(10θ​)$ with a magnitude of $1$ and an argument of $10θ​$.


Use De Moivre's theorem to show that $zn+(z1​)n=2cos(10nθ​)$. [2]





Hence, write down $z2+(z1​)2$ in terms of $cos(5θ​)$.


Hence, write down $z4+(z1​)4$ in terms of $cos(52θ​)$.


Hence, write down $z6+(z1​)6$ in terms of $cos(53θ​)$. [3]





Find $(z+z1​)6$ in terms of $cos(10θ​)$. [1]



Use the binomial theorem to fully expand $(z+z1​)6$ in terms of $z$. [2]



Hence, combine your answers to part (b), (c) and (d) to show that
$$$64cos6(10θ​)​=20+30cos(5θ​)+12cos(52θ​)+2cos(53θ​)​$$$
[3]



Hence, find $∫cos6(10θ​)dθ.$  [4]



Miggy designs Margarita glasses. The glasses are composed of two parts; the bowl and the base. The height of the bowl is $h$cm above the base. For the rest of this question you can ignore the base. This is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b28025d6-e155-4e93-9b74-51d2e6812367/images/42dcbffc-9db0-4465-becb-619763469182/AA1178_q1.JPEG)


Miggy likes to create mathematical models of his glasses. He does this by rotating the glass $90∘$ anti-clockwise and modelling the shape of the outside of the glass.
The shape of the glass is modelled by the function $y=f(x)$.
Miggy can then form the glass by rotating $f(x)$ by $2π$ radians about the $x−$axis. This is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b28025d6-e155-4e93-9b74-51d2e6812367/images/9cd71da5-c4b1-4ae3-92fe-3e7b1a71f560/AA1178_q2.JPEG)


For Miggy's latest creation he modelled the shape of the bowl using the function $f(x)=4cos3(10x​)$. Where $x≥0$ and measured in centimeters.
The bottom of the stem of the bowl occurs at the first positive root of $f(x)=0$.


Show that $h=5π$ cm. [3]



Show that the exact volume contained inside the bowl is $25π2$ cm$3$. [5]
list.markScheme:
We can apply De Moivre's theorem to both terms
$$$zn​=cis(10nθ​)=cos(10nθ​)+isin(10nθ​)​​z1​=z−n=cis(10−nθ​)z1​=z−n=cos(10−nθ​)+isin(10−nθ​)​$$$
Recall $cos$ is an even function and $sin$ is odd. Therefore $cos(−x)=cosx$ and $sin(−x)=−sinx$, therefore
$$$hack​(M1)​$$$
$$$​=cos(10nθ​)+isin(10nθ​)​​z1​=zn=cos(10nθ​)−isin(10nθ​)​$$$
Combining the two terms we get
$$$zn+z−n​=cos(10nθ​)+isin(10nθ​)​+cos(10nθ​)−isin(10nθ​)​=2cos(10nθ​)​​A1​$$$


We can use the identity we proved in part (a) to help us in this part

For this part $n=2$
$$$z2+z−2​=2cos(102θ​)=2cos(5θ​)​​A1​$$$

Now $n=4$
$$$z4+z−4​=2cos(104θ​)=2cos(52θ​)​​A1​$$$

Finally $n=6$
$$$z6+z−6​=2cos(106θ​)=2cos(53θ​)​​A1​$$$




We can use the identity from part (a) with $n=1$
$$$(z+z1​)6​=(z1+z−1)6=(2cos(10θ​))6=64cos6(10θ​)​​A1​$$$


Using the binomial theorem
$$$​(z+z1​)6=z6+(16​)z5×z1​+(26​)z4×z21​+(36​)z3×z31​+(46​)z2×z41​+(56​)z×z51​+z61​​(M1)​$$$
We can resolve the binomial coefficients using a G.D.C. and simplify
$$$​=z6+6z4+15z2+20+z215​+z46​+z61​​​A1​$$$


First we can use our answer from part (d) to write out the expansion in terms of $z$
$$$(z+z1​)6​=z6+6z4+15z2+20+z215​+z46​+z61​​(A1)​$$$
Now we can group the terms in the form $±n$ so we can use our previous answers
$$$​=z6+z61​+6(z4+z41​)+15(z2+z21​)+20​(M1)​$$$
We can now use our answers from part (b)
$$$​=2cos(53θ​)+6×2cos(52θ​)+15×2cos(5θ​)+20​A1​$$$
Now we can rewrite the L.H.S. using our answer from part (c) and then simplify
$$$64cos6(10θ​)​=20+2cos(53θ​)+6×2cos(52θ​)+15×2cos(5θ​)64cos6(10θ​)=20+30cos(5θ​)+12cos(52θ​)+2cos(53θ​)​​$$$


Rewrite the integral using our result from part (e) so that each term is a single power of $cos$.
$$$∫64cos6(10θ​)dθ∫cos6(10θ​)dθ​=∫[20+30cos(5θ​)+12cos(52θ​)+2cos(53θ​)]dθ=641​∫[20+30cos(5θ​)+12cos(52θ​)+2cos(53θ​)]dθ=641​[20θ+150sin(5θ​)+30sin(52θ​)+310​sin(53θ​)]+C=165​θ+3275​sin(5θ​)+3215​sin(52θ​)+965​sin(53θ​)+C​​M1A1A2​$$$


As we are told the stem of the bowl is the first zero of $f(x)$ we need to solve the following equation
$$$4cos3(10x​)cos(10x​)10x​10x​x​=0=0=arccos0=2π​=210π​=5π​... as required.​M1A1​$$$


We can use the volume of revolution formula, with the answer from part (g)(ii), from $x=0$ to $x=5π$
$$$hack​(A1)​$$$
$$$V​=π∫05π​[f(x)]2dx=π∫05π​[4cos3(10x​)]2dx=16π∫05π​cos6(10x​)dx​$$$
We can use our answer to part (f)
$$$hack​(M1)​$$$
$$$​=16π[165​x+3275​sin(5θ​)+3215​sin(52θ​)+965​sin(53θ​)]05π​=16π[(165​×5π+3275​sin(55π​)+3215​sin(510π​)+965​sin(515π​))−(165​×0+3275​sin(50​)+3215​sin(50​)+965​sin(50​))​]​A1​$$$
Now simplify using the fact that $sinπ=sin2π=sin3π=0$
$$$hack​(A1)​$$$
$$$​=16π(1625π​)=25π2cm3​... as required.​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
Consider the complex numbers $z1​=−1+3​ai$ and $z2​=3a+13​(a−1)​+i$.  Where $a∈R,a=−31​$.
Another complex number is defined such that $z3​=z1​z2​​$.
Let $θ=arg(z3​)$, where $−π≤θ≤π$.


Show that $tanθ$ is constant for $a∈R,a=−31​$. [4]



Hence, find the two possible values of $θ$ and the intervals of $a$ for which they will occur.[3]
list.markScheme:
Begin by dividing the two complex numbers
$$$z3​​=−1+3​ai3a+13​(a−1)​+i​​$$$
Multiply the top and bottom by the complex conjugate of $z1​$, then simplify
$$$​=−1+3​ai3a+13​(a−1)​+i​×−1−3​ai−1−3​ai​=3a2+13a+13​(a−1)(−1−3​ai)​+(−1−3​ai)i​​A1​$$$
Write the numerator as a single fraction and simplify
$$$​=3a2+11​(3a+13​(a−1)(−1−3​ai)+(−i+3​a)(1+3a)​)=3a2+11​(3a+13​(−a−3​a2i+1+3​ai)−i−3ai+3​a+33​a2​)​A1​$$$
Cancel out terms.
$$$​=3a2+11​(3a+1−3​a​−3a2i+3​+3ai−i−3ai+3​a​+33​a2​)=3a2+11​(3a+13​+33​a2−(3a2+1)i​)=3a2+1​1​(3a+13​(3a2+1)​−(3a2+1)i​​)=3a+11​(3​−i)​A1​$$$
Hence we can find $tanθ$ independent of $a$
$$$R1$$$
$$$​=−3​1​​$$$
Therefore\hspace{1em}$tanθ is constant for a ∈R,a=−31​​$


First we can find the two values of $θ$
$$$θ​=arctan(−3​1​)=−6π​,65π​​A1​$$$
We can now sketch two representations of $z3​=3a+11​(3​−i)$ on Argand diagrams which both have the same value for $tanθ$.
$$$M1$$$
When $3a+11​>0$ then $θ=−6π​$ and when $3a+11​<0$ then $θ=65π​$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e096ec96-6e1c-4e9d-8c5d-46e07f491b2a/images/1194ed2c-6596-414f-857d-5b89d8fd0861/ans1.png)


We can use a sign diagram (or a sketch) to determine the conditions for the sign of $3a+11​$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e096ec96-6e1c-4e9d-8c5d-46e07f491b2a/images/6171c81d-eaa5-4a08-9737-530f9d0d738f/ans2.png)


Therefore $3a+11​>0$ when $a>−31​$ and $3a+11​<0$ when $a<−31​$
Hence
$$$θ=−6π​ for a>−31​ and θ=65π​ for a<−31​​A1$$$

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Use de Moivre's theorem to find the value of
$[cos(6π​)+isin(6π​)]12$.
[2]



Use mathematical induction to prove that
$$$(cosα−isinα)n=cos(nα)−isin(nα)for all n∈Z+.$$$
[6]



Let
$w=cosα+isinα$.


Find an expression in terms of $α$ for
$wn−(w∗)n$, $n∈Z+$, where $w∗$ is
the complex conjugate of $w$. [2]





Show that $ww∗=1$.


Write down and simplify the binomial expansion of
$(w−w∗)3$ in terms of $w$ and $w∗$.


Hence show that
$sin(3α)=3sinα−4sin3α$. [5]





Hence solve
$4sin3α+(2cosα−3)sinα=0$ for
$0≤α≤π$. [6]
list.markScheme:
Using de Moivre's theorem, we find
$$$[cos(6π​)+isin(6π​)]12​=cos(612π​)+isin(612π​)=cos2π+isin2π=1​​$$$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$(cosα−isinα)n=cos(nα)−isin(nα)[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n∈Z+$.


Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$(cosα−isinα)1​=cosα−isinα=cos(1⋅α)−isin(1⋅α)​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$(cosα−isinα)k=cos(kα)−isin(kα)(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$(cosα−isinα)k+1=cos((k+1)α)−isin((k+1)α)(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$​(cosα−isinα)k+1==(cosα−isinα)kcosα−(cosα−isinα)k(isinα)=[cos(kα)−isin(kα)]cosα−[cos(kα)−isin(kα)](isinα)[by (IH)]=cos(kα)cosα−isin(kα)cosα−icos(kα)sinα−sin(kα)sinα=[cos(kα)cosα−sin(kα)sinα]−i[sin(kα)cosα+cos(kα)sinα]=cos((k+1)α)−isin((k+1)α)[by compound angle formulas]​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.


Using de Moivre's theorem and the identity $(2)$ from part
(b), we find
$$$wn−(w∗)n​=(cosα+isinα)n−(cosα−isinα)n=[cos(nα)+isin(nα)]−[cos(nα)−isin(nα)]=2isin(nα)​(3)​$$$




The product of $w$ and its conjugate is
$$$ww∗​=(cosα+isinα)(cosα−isinα)=cos2α−icosαsinα+isinαcosα+sin2α=cos2α+sin2α=1​​$$$


If we simplify the binomial expansion of $(w−w∗)3$, we
get
$$$(w−w∗)3​=w3−3w2w∗+3w(w∗)2−(w∗)3=w3−3w(ww∗)+3w∗(ww∗)−(w∗)3=w3−3w+3w∗−(w∗)3[by part (d) (i)]=w3−(w∗)3−3(w−w∗)​​$$$


Substituting $n=1$ and $n=3$ in the identity $(3)$ from part
(c), we have
$$$n=1n=3​:w−(w∗)=2isinα:w3−(w∗)3=2isin(3α)​$$$
Hence, from part d (ii), we obtain
$$$(w−w∗)3(2isinα)3−8isin3α4sin3α​=w3−(w∗)3−3(w−w∗)=2isin(3α)−3(2isinα)=2isin(3α)−6isinα=−sin(3α)+3sinα​$$$
$$$sin(3α)=3sinα−4sin3α​$$$




If we rewrite the given equation, we have
$$$4sin3α+(2cosα−3)sinα2sinαcosαsin(2α)​=0=3sinα−4sin3α=sin(3α)[by part (d) (iii)](4)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(4)$ for $α$, we find
$$$αα​=0or3α=kπ−2α[where k is an odd integer]=0orα=5kπ​[where k=1,3,5 since α∈[0,π]]​$$$
$$$α=0,5π​,53π​,π​$$$

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Solve the equation $sin(x+90°)=2cos(x−60°)$,
$0°<x<360°$.  [5]



Show that $sin15°+cos15°=26​​$.
[4]



Let
$z=1−cos4θ−isin4θ$,
for $z∈C$, $0<θ<2π​$.


Find the modulus and argument of $z$. Express each answer
in its simplest form.


Hence find the fourth roots of $z$ in modulus-argument form.
[11]
list.markScheme:
Using the compound angle formulas for sine and cosine, we find
$$$sin(x+90°)sinxcos90°+cosxsin90°sinx(0)+cosx(1)cosx0sinx​=2cos(x−60°)=2cosxcos60°+2sinxsin60°=2cosx(21​)+2sinx(23​​)=cosx+3​sinx=3​sinx=0​$$$
$$$x=180°​[since 0°<x<360°]$$$


Using the compound angle formula for sine, we have
$$$sin15°​=sin(45°−30°)=sin45°cos30°−cos45°sin30°=22​​⋅23​​−22​​⋅21​=46​−2​​​$$$
Using the compound
angle formula for cosine, we have
$$$cos15°​=cos(45°−30°)=cos45°cos30°+sin45°sin30°=22​​⋅23​​+22​​⋅21​=46​+2​​​$$$
Hence we obtain
$$$sin15°+cos15°​=46​−2​​+46​+2​​=26​​​​$$$




The modulus of $z$ is
$$$∣z∣​=[(1−cos4θ)2+(sin4θ)2]21​=[1−2cos4θ+(cos4θ)2+(sin4θ)2]21​=[2−2cos4θ]21​=[2−2(1−2(sin2θ)2)]21​[by double-angle formula]=[4(sin2θ)2]21​=2∣sin2θ∣=2sin2θ​[since sin2θ>0 for 0<θ<90°]​$$$
Using the double-angle formulas for sine and cosine, we have
$$$tan(argz)​=1−cos4θ(−sin4θ)​=−1−[1−2(sin2θ)2]2sin2θcos2θ​=−sin2θcos2θ​=−cot2θ=−tan(2π​−2θ)=tan(2θ−2π​)​$$$
Hence the argument of $z$ is
$argz=2θ−2π​​$


Hence, using part c (i) and de Moivre's theorem, we find
$$$z41​​=[2sin2θcis(2θ−2π​)]41​=42sin2θ​cis(42θ−π/2+2kπ​)=42sin2θ​cis(2θ​−8π​+2kπ​)​​$$$
for $k=0,1,2,3$.

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
The complex number $z$ is a root of the equation $∣z+4i∣=∣z−10i∣$.


Show that the imaginary part of $z$ is $3$.[2]



Let $ω1​$ and $ω2​$ be two possible values of $z$ such that $∣z∣=6$.


If $ω1​$ is in the first quadrant sketch both solutions on an Argand diagram.


Hence find the arguments of $ω1​$ and $ω2​$.[4]





A different complex number, $v$, is defined such that
$$$v​=−iω1k​ω2​​​$$$
Where $k$ is a real number that can take any value in the interval $−10≤k≤10$ and $−π≤arg(−i)≤π$.




Find $arg(v)$ in terms of $k$ and $π$.


Hence find all possible values of $k$ such that $v$ is a real number.[8]
list.markScheme:
We are told $z$ is a complex number, therefore $z$ is of the form $a+bi$ where $a,b∈R$.
Hence we can rewrite the equation in terms of $a$ and $b$ to get
$$$∣a+bi+4i∣​=∣a+bi−10i∣​$$$
If we collect together the real and imaginary parts it is easier to consider the magnitude of the number
$$$∣a+i(b+4)∣​=∣a+i(b−10)∣​$$$
Recall the magnitude of a complex number $∣a+bi∣=a2+b2​$
$$$a2+(b+4)2​a2+(b+4)2a2+b2+8b+16​=a2+(b−10)2​=a2+(b−10)2=a2+b2−20b+100​M1​$$$
We can find $b$
$$$28bb​=84=3​A1​$$$
Therefore $Im(z)=3​$ as required.




The red dashed circle of radius $6$ represents the fact that $∣z∣=6$. Therefore $z$ must lie somewhere on this circle.
The blue horizontal line shows the possible values of $z$ when $Im(z)=3$, with $ω1​$ being in the first quadrant.
$z$ must lie on both the red circle and blue line


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e18d312d-04c9-41ff-b182-e17af82510c4/images/821110ca-66b4-4319-b7fd-6f5016f30578/AA1282-a1.JPEG)


$$$​ω1​ and ω2​ both have imaginary values of 3.​Correct quadrants for ω1​ and ω2​.​​A1A1​$$$


Using trigonometric ratios we can find $arg(ω1​)$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e18d312d-04c9-41ff-b182-e17af82510c4/images/7fceded4-ee63-4951-8a39-8f99d62bc44b/AA1282-a2.JPEG)


$$$sin[arg(ω1​)][arg(ω1​)]arg(ω1​)​=63​=sin−1(21​)=6π​​​A1​$$$
Using the symmetries of the diagram
$$$sin[arg(ω2​)]​=π−sin[arg(ω1​)]=65π​​​A1​$$$






In this question we are combining complex numbers and working with their arguments.
For questions of this nature it is most efficient to use Euler's form of a complex number.
Recall
$$$z​=reiθ​$$$
Where $r$ is the magnitude of the number and $θ$ the argument.
Hence, using our answers from part (b) we can write
$$$ω1​ω2​​=6ei6π​=6ei65π​​$$$
If we raise $ω1​$ to the power $k$, using De Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$ω1​​=6kei6kπ​​(M1)​$$$
Next we need to consider how to write $−i$ in Euler's form.
Here is a sketch of $−i$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e18d312d-04c9-41ff-b182-e17af82510c4/images/e2827066-697d-4620-8212-aee865261ae4/AA1282-a3.JPEG)


We can see that the magnitude is $1$ and the argument is $−2π​$, angles measured in the clockwise direction are negative and we are told in the question that $−π≤arg(−i)≤π$.
Hence we get
$$$−i​=e−i2π​​(A1)​$$$
Putting these results together for $v$ we get
$$$v​=−iω1k​ω2​​=e−i2π​6kei6kπ​×6ei65π​​​M1​$$$
Recall we want to find the argument of $v$, hence we need to simplify our expression so that it is in standard Euler's form $→z=reiθ$.
We can now see the advantage of using Euler's form. To combine the angles we need to resolve the powers of $e$ using basic index laws
$$$​=6×6kei6kπ​+65π​−(−2π​)=6k+1ei6kπ​+65π​+2π​=6k+1ei6kπ​+65π​+63π​=6k+1ei6kπ​+68π​=6k+1ei6π​(k+8)​M1​$$$
By looking at the exponent of $e$ we can find the argument of $v$ in terms of $k$ and $π$, hence
$$$arg(v)​=6π​(k+8)​​A1​$$$


$v$ is a real number when it lies entirely on the real axis (Re $z$).
Therefore its argument must be a multiple of $π$. Note $0$ is a multiple of $π$.
We can form an equation for the argument. We aren't sure how many multiples of $π$ we'll need so we can pick a few to get us started
$$$6π​(k+8)​=...−2π,−π,0,π,2π...​(M1)​$$$
We can now multiply by $6$ and divide by $π$ to get
$$$k+8​=...−12,−6,0,6,12...​A1​$$$
Subtracting $8$ from each answer we get
$$$k​=...−20,−14,−8,−2,4...​$$$
Recall that $−10≤k≤10$.
Hence we reject the first two answers. We may have missed one on the positive side.
$$$6π​(k+8)k+8k​=3π=18=10​$$$
Hence all answers in the interval for $k$ are
$$$k​=−8,−2,4,10​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
This questions will investigate a method to obtain Cardano's formula
using elementary properties of complex numbers and algebraic
expressions.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e10af45-5057-4e0b-a99d-9c029231b5d3/images/ea464ab6-a275-4781-9cd3-0b243a99f8b0/AA918%20-%20dia.png)



The roots, of magnitude $1$, described above can be written in polar form such that $ωn​=cosθ+isinθ$. The argument, $θ$, is such that $0≤θ≤2π$.


Show that  $ω0​=1$ and find the remaining roots, $ω1​$ and $ω2​$, in polar form.


Show that $ω1​ω2​=1$.


Show that $ω12​+ω22​=ω1​+ω2​$.


Hence, show that $ω1​+ω2​=−1$ in Cartesian form. [7]





Consider the cubic equation $x3−3px+2q=0$ for $p$, $q∈R$.
Assume we can write it in a factorised form such that $x3−3px+2q=(x+α+β)(x+ω1​α+ω2​β)(x+ω2​α+ω1​β)$.



Identify the roots of the factorised form above, find the product of the roots, then use the results from part (a) to show that $2q=α3+β3$

Another formula for the roots $r1​$, $r2​$ and $r3​$ of the cubic equation $ax3+bx2+cx+d$ states that $r1​r2​+r1​r3​+r2​r3​=ac​$.


Using the roots identified from part (b) (i), the formula above, and the results from part (a), show that $p=αβ$.


Using parts (b) (i) and (b) (ii), write $α$ and $β$ in terms of $p$ and $q$.


Hence, show that $−3q+q2−p3​​−3q−q2−p3​​$ is a root of the cubic equation $x3−3px+2q=0$. [12]





Now, consider a more general cubic equation $x3+sx+t=0$, where $s$, $t∈R$.




By substituting $s=−3p$ and $t=2q$ prove Cardano's formula, which states that $3−2t​+4t2​+27s3​​​+3−2t​−4t2​+27s3​​​$
is a root of the cubic equation $x3+sx+t=0$.


Use Cardano's formula to find the exact solution to $x3+6x+5=0$.


Using the substitution $z=x−1$ and Cardano's formula, find an exact solution to $z3+3z2−6=0$.[9]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$z3z3​=1=cos0+isin0​$$$
Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get
$$$z​=(cos0+isin0)31​=cos(32kπ​)+isin(32kπ​)[for k=0,1,2]​$$$
Hence the roots of the equation $z3=1$ are
$$$k=0k=1k=2​:ω0​=cos0+isin0=1​:ω1​=cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)​:ω2​=cos(34π​)+isin(34π​)​​A1A1A1​$$$


When we multiply complex numbers together we must add their arguments.
$$$ω1​ω2​​=cos(32π​+34π​)+isin(32π​+34π​)=cos2π+isin2π=1​​M1​$$$


Using part (i), we can find $ω12​$
$$$ω12​​=cos(32π​+32π​)+isin(32π​+32π​)=cos(34π​)+isin(34π​)=ω2​​$$$
Similarly we can find $ω22​$
$$$ω22​​=cos(34π​+34π​)+isin(34π​+34π​)=cos(38π​)+isin(38π​)​M1​$$$
$arg(38π​)=arg(32π​)$, hence
$$$ω22​​=ω1​​A1​$$$
Finally
$$$ω12​+ω22​​=ω2​+ω1​​​$$$


Using part (i), we get
$$$ω2​+ω1​​=cos(34π​)+isin(34π​)+cos(32π​)+isin(32π​)​$$$
Evaluate the trig functions
$$$​=−21​−23​​i+−21​+23​​i=−1​​A1​$$$






We can rewrite RHS of the given formula to identify the roots of the polynomial
$$$x3−3px+2q​=(x−(−α−β))(x−(−ω1​α−ω2​β))(x−(−ω2​α−ω1​β))​$$$
Hence the three roots are $(−α−β)$, $(−ω1​α−ω2​β)$ and $(−ω2​α−ω1​β)$.
Using the formula for the product of the roots of a polynomial, we get
$$$(−α−β)(−ω1​α−ω2​β)(−ω2​α−ω1​β)​=−12q​​M1​$$$
We can factorise out negative one from each root and then simplify
$$$−1×(α+β)×(−1)×(ω1​α+ω2​β)×(−1)×(ω2​α+ω1​β)(α+β)(ω1​α+ω2​β)(ω2​α+ω1​β)​=−2q=2q​$$$
Next, expand and simplify, then use previous question parts to eliminate $ω1​$ and $ω2​$
$$$(α+β)(ω1​ω2​α2+ω12​αβ+ω22​αβ+ω1​ω2​β2)(α+β)(α2+ω12​αβ+ω22​αβ+β2)(α+β)(α2+αβ(ω12​+ω22​)+β2)​=2q=2qusing part (a) (ii)=2q​A1​$$$
Now using (a)(iii) and (a)(iv), $ω12​+ω22​=−1$, and expanding we can write
$$$(α+β)(α2−αβ+β2)​=2qα3+β3=2q​​A1​$$$


Using the three identified roots of the polynomial described in the previous part
$$$r1​r2​r3​​=(−α−β)=−(α+β)=(−ω1​α−ω2​β)=−(ω1​α+ω2​β)=(−ω2​α−ω1​β)=−(ω2​α+ω1​β)​$$$
We can rewrite the LHS of the given formula, using the results above, and then simplify
$$$​r1​r2​+r1​r3​+r2​r3​=(α+β)(ω1​α+ω2​β)+(α+β)(ω2​α+ω1​β)+(ω1​α+ω2​β)(ω2​α+ω1​β)​$$$
$$$=​(α+β)((ω1​+ω2​)α+(ω1​+ω2​)β)+(ω1​α+ω2​β)(ω2​α+ω1​β)​$$$
From part (a)(iv) we can use $ω1​+ω2​=−1$ and by expanding the third term we can write
$$$=​(α+β)(−α−β)+ω1​ω2​α2+ω12​αβ+ω22​αβ+ω1​ω2​β2​M1​$$$
From part (a)(iii) and part (a)(iv) we can use $ω12​+ω22​=−1$ and hence write
$$$==​(α+β)(−α−β)+ω1​ω2​α2+αβ(ω12​+ω22​)+ω1​ω2​β2(α+β)(−α−β)+ω1​ω2​α2−αβ+ω1​ω2​β2​A1​$$$
From part (a)(ii) $ω1​ω2​=1$ we can write
$$$=​(α+β)(−α−β)+α2−αβ+β2​$$$
Expand the remaining bracket and simplify
$$$==​−α2−2αβ−β2+α2−αβ+β2−3αβ​A1​$$$
We can equate this to the RHS of the forumula given in the question
$$$−3αβ​=ac​​M1​$$$
The parameter $c$ refers to the coefficient of the $x$ term and parameter $a$ refers to the coefficient of $x3$ in the polynomial $x3−3px+2q$, hence
$$$−3αβ​=1−3p​p=αβ​​$$$


From part (ii) find $β$ in terms of $α$ and $p$
$$$β​=αp​​$$$
Then substitute this into the relationship found in part (i) and rearrange so the RHS is zero
$$$α3+(αp​)3α6−2qα3+p3​=2q=0​M1​$$$
The is a disguised quadratic for $α3$, we can solve it using the quadratic formula and hence find $α$ in terms of $p$ and $q$
$$$α3​=22q±4q2−4p3​​α=3q±q2−p3​​​​A1​$$$
Now, substituting the result for $α$ back into the relation found in (i) and we have
$$$β3β3​=2q−α3=2q−(q±q2−p3​)=q∓q2−p3​β=3q∓q2−p3​​​​M1A1​$$$


As $α$  and $β$ have opposite signs inside the cubic root and $x+α+β$ is a factor of the equation we conclude that
$−α−β is a root of the equation given by−3q+q2−p3​​−3q−q2−p3​​.​A1$






Substituting $s=−3p$ and $t=2q$ we have the equation
$$$x3−3p+2q​=0​$$$
and according to part (b) (iv) we have the root
$$$−3q+q2−p3​​​−3q−q2−p3​​​$$$
Reflecting on the desired result, we can rewrite each term by factorising with $−1$
$$$=3−(q+q2−p3​)​=3−q−q2−p3​​​+3−(q−q2−p3​)​+3−q+q2−p3​​​(M1)​$$$
Now, substituting back $p=−3s​$ and $q=2t​$ we obtain
$$$​=3−2t​−(2t​)2−(−3s​)3​​+3−2t​+(2t​)2−(−3s​)3​​=3−2t​−4t2​+27s3​​​+3−2t​+4t2​+27s3​​​=3−2t​+4t2​+27s3​​​+3−2t​−4t2​+27s3​​​​​M1A1​$$$


Using Cardano's formula, with $s=6$ and $t=5$, we get
$$$=​3−25​+425​+27216​​​+3−25​−425​+27216​​​3−25​+457​​​+3−25​−457​​​=32−5+57​​​+32−5−57​​​​​M1A1​$$$


Substituting $z=x−1$, we get
$$$(x−1)3+3(x−1)2−6x3−3x2+3x−1+3(x2−2x+1)−6x3−3x2+3x−1+3x2−6x+3−6x3−3x−4​=0=0=0=0​M1A1​$$$
Now, using Cardano's formula, with $s=−3$ and $t=−4$, we obtain
$$$x=x=​3−2−4​+416​+27−27​​​+3−2−4​−416​+27−27​​​32+3​​+32−3​​​A1​$$$
Recall, $z=x−1$, therefore, a solution to $z3+3z2−6=0$ is
$$$​z=−1+32+3​​+32−3​​​​A1​$$$
